content.description:
The content of the form is structured in the following way:
  • Add a Title or Toolbar control to start a new group (FormContainer).
  • Add a Label control to start a new row (FormElement).
  • Add controls as input fields, text fields or other as needed.
  • Use LayoutData to influence the layout for special cases in the single controls. For example, if a ResponsiveLayout is used as a layout, the form content is weighted using weight 3 for the labels and weight 5 for the fields part. By default the label column is 192 pixels wide. If your input controls should influence their width, you can add sap.ui.layout.ResponsiveFlowLayoutData to them via setLayoutData method. Ensure that the sum of the weights in the ResponsiveFlowLayoutData is not more than 5, as this is the total width of the input control part of each form row.
Example for a row where the Input weight 4 and the second Input weight 1 (using ResponsiveLayout): 
new sap.m.Label({text:"Label"});
new sap.m.Input({value:"Weight 4", layoutData: new sap.ui.layout.ResponsiveFlowLayoutData({weight:4})}),
new sap.m.Input({value:"Weight 1", layoutData: new sap.ui.layout.ResponsiveFlowLayoutData({weight:1})}),
For example, if a ResponsiveGridLayout is used as a layout, there are 12 cells in one row. Depending on the screen size the labels use the defined labelSpan. The remaining cells are used for the fields (and emptySpan if defined). The available cells are distributed to all fields in the row. If one field should use a fixed number of cells you can add sap.ui.layout.GridData to them via setLayoutData method. If there are additional fields in the row they will get the remaining cells. Example for a row with two Input controls where one uses four cells on small screens, one cell on medium screens and 2 cells on larger screens (using ResponsiveGridLayout): 
new sap.m.Label({text:"Label"});
new sap.m.Input({value:"auto size"}),
new sap.m.Input({value:"fix size", layoutData: new sap.ui.layout.GridData({span: "XL1 L1 M2 S4"})}),
Warning: Do not put any layout or other container controls in here. This could damage the visual layout, keyboard support and screen-reader support. Only labels, titles, toolbars and form controls are allowed. Views are also not supported. Allowed form controls implement the interface sap.ui.core.IFormContent. If editable controls are used as content, the editable property must be set to true, otherwise to false. If the editable property is set incorrectly, there will be visual issues like wrong label alignment or wrong spacing between the controls.
content.helpDescription:
The content of the form is structured in the following way:
  • Add a Title or Toolbar control to start a new group (FormContainer).
  • Add a Label control to start a new row (FormElement).
  • Add controls as input fields, text fields or other as needed.
  • Use LayoutData to influence the layout for special cases in the single controls. For example, if a ResponsiveLayout is used as a layout, the form content is weighted using weight 3 for the labels and weight 5 for the fields part. By default the label column is 192 pixels wide. If your input controls should influence their width, you can add sap.ui.layout.ResponsiveFlowLayoutData to them via setLayoutData method. Ensure that the sum of the weights in the ResponsiveFlowLayoutData is not more than 5, as this is the total width of the input control part of each form row.
Example for a row where the Input weight 4 and the second Input weight 1 (using ResponsiveLayout): 
new sap.m.Label({text:"Label"});
new sap.m.Input({value:"Weight 4", layoutData: new sap.ui.layout.ResponsiveFlowLayoutData({weight:4})}),
new sap.m.Input({value:"Weight 1", layoutData: new sap.ui.layout.ResponsiveFlowLayoutData({weight:1})}),
For example, if a ResponsiveGridLayout is used as a layout, there are 12 cells in one row. Depending on the screen size the labels use the defined labelSpan. The remaining cells are used for the fields (and emptySpan if defined). The available cells are distributed to all fields in the row. If one field should use a fixed number of cells you can add sap.ui.layout.GridData to them via setLayoutData method. If there are additional fields in the row they will get the remaining cells. Example for a row with two Input controls where one uses four cells on small screens, one cell on medium screens and 2 cells on larger screens (using ResponsiveGridLayout): 
new sap.m.Label({text:"Label"});
new sap.m.Input({value:"auto size"}),
new sap.m.Input({value:"fix size", layoutData: new sap.ui.layout.GridData({span: "XL1 L1 M2 S4"})}),
Warning: Do not put any layout or other container controls in here. This could damage the visual layout, keyboard support and screen-reader support. Only labels, titles, toolbars and form controls are allowed. Views are also not supported. Allowed form controls implement the interface sap.ui.core.IFormContent. If editable controls are used as content, the editable property must be set to true, otherwise to false. If the editable property is set incorrectly, there will be visual issues like wrong label alignment or wrong spacing between the controls.

Note: This property is only used if a ResponsiveGridLayout is used as a layout.

editable.description: Applies a device-specific and theme-specific line height and label alignment to the form rows if the form has editable content. If set, all (not only the editable) rows of the form will get the line height of editable fields. The accessibility aria-readonly attribute is set according to this property. Note: The setting of the property has no influence on the editable functionality of the form's content.
editable.helpDescription: Applies a device-specific and theme-specific line height and label alignment to the form rows if the form has editable content. If set, all (not only the editable) rows of the form will get the line height of editable fields. The accessibility aria-readonly attribute is set according to this property. Note: The setting of the property has no influence on the editable functionality of the form's content.

minWidth.description: The overall minimum width in pixels that is used for the SimpleForm. If the available width is below the given minWidth the SimpleForm will create a new row for the next group (FormContainer). The default value is -1, meaning that inner groups (FormContainers) will be stacked until maxContainerCols is reached, irrespective of whether a width is reached or the available parents width is reached. Note: This property is only used if a ResponsiveLayout is used as a layout.
minWidth.helpDescription: The overall minimum width in pixels that is used for the SimpleForm. If the available width is below the given minWidth the SimpleForm will create a new row for the next group (FormContainer). The default value is -1, meaning that inner groups (FormContainers) will be stacked until maxContainerCols is reached, irrespective of whether a width is reached or the available parents width is reached. Note: This property is only used if a ResponsiveLayout is used as a layout.

labelSpanM.description: Default span for labels in medium size. Note: If adjustLabelSpanThis is set, this property is used for full-size FormContainers. If more than one FormContainer is in one line, labelSpanL is used. Note: This property is only used if a ResponsiveGridLayout is used as a layout.

adjustLabelSpan.description: If set, the usage of labelSpanL and labelSpanM are dependent on the number of FormContainers in one row. If only one FormContainer is displayed in one row, labelSpanM is used to define the size of the label. This is the same for medium and large Forms. This is done to align the labels on forms where full-size FormContainers and multiple-column rows are used in the same Form (because every FormContainer has its own grid inside). If not set, the usage of labelSpanL and labelSpanM are dependent on the Form size. The number of FormContainers doesn't matter in this case. Note: This property is only used if a ResponsiveGridLayout is used as a layout.
adjustLabelSpan.helpDescription: If set, the usage of labelSpanL and labelSpanM are dependent on the number of FormContainers in one row. sap.ui.commons.CalloutBase.description: CalloutBase is a building block for Callout. Do not use it directly. Use the Callout control instead
sap.ui.commons.CalloutBase.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new CalloutBase. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Events
    • {@link #event:open open} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:close close} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:beforeOpen beforeOpen} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:opened opened} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.TooltipBase#constructor sap.ui.core.TooltipBase} can be used as well.
sap.ui.commons.CalloutBase.helpDescription:
Deprecated! Since 1.38 undefined
CalloutBase is a building block for Callout. Do not use it directly. Use the Callout control instead

sap.ui.commons.MenuItem.constructorDescription: Constructor for a new MenuItem element.
sap.ui.commons.MenuItem.helpDescription:
Deprecated! Since 1.21.0 Please use the element sap.ui.unified.MenuItem of the library sap.ui.unified instead.
Standard item to be used inside a menu. A menu item represents an action which can be selected by the user in the menu or it can provide a submenu to organize the actions hierarchically.

DeprecatedInfo.description: Please use the element sap.ui.unified.MenuItem of the library sap.ui.unified instead.

layoutData.description: Defines the layout constraints for this control when it is used inside a Layout. LayoutData classes are typed classes and must match the embedding Layout. See VariantLayoutData for aggregating multiple alternative LayoutData instances to a single Element.
layoutData.helpDescription: Defines the layout constraints for this control when it is used inside a Layout. LayoutData classes are typed classes and must match the embedding Layout. See VariantLayoutData for aggregating multiple alternative LayoutData instances to a single Element.

submenu.description: An optional submenu of the item which is opened when the item is selected by the user.
submenu.helpDescription: An optional submenu of the item which is opened when the item is selected by the user.

tooltip.description:
The tooltip that should be shown for this Element.

Can either be an instance of a TooltipBase subclass or a simple string.
tooltip.helpDescription:

models.description: A map of model instances to which the object should be attached. The models are keyed by their model name. For the default model, String(undefined) is expected.

visible.description: Invisible items do not appear in the menu.
visible.helpDescription: Invisible items do not appear in the menu.

objectBindings.description: A map of model instances to which the object should be attached. The models are keyed by their model name. For the default model, String(undefined) is expected.

icon.description: Defines the icon of the {@link sap.ui.core.IconPool sap.ui.core.IconPool} or an image which should be displayed on the item.
icon.helpDescription: Defines the icon of the {@link sap.ui.core.IconPool sap.ui.core.IconPool} or an image which should be displayed on the item.

text.description: Defines the text which should be displayed on the item.
text.helpDescription: Defines the text which should be displayed on the item.

id.description: Unique ID of this instance. If not given, a so called autoID will be generated by the framework. AutoIDs use a unique prefix that must not be used for Ids that the application (or other code) creates. It can be configured option 'autoIDPrefix', see {@link sap.ui.core.Configuration}.

startsSection.description: Defines whether a visual separator should be rendered before the item. Note: If an item is invisible also the separator of this item is not shown.
startsSection.helpDescription: Defines whether a visual separator should be rendered before the item. Note: If an item is invisible also the separator of this item is not shown.

enabled.description: When an item is disabled the item can not be selected by the user. The enabled property of the item has no effect when the menu of the item is disabled ({@link sap.ui.unified.Menu#getEnabled Menu#getEnabled}).
enabled.helpDescription: When an item is disabled the item can not be selected by the user. The enabled property of the item has no effect when the menu of the item is disabled ({@link sap.ui.unified.Menu#getEnabled Menu#getEnabled}).

sap.ui.commons.RowRepeaterSorter.description: This element is used by the RowRepeater and allows to define a sorter in this context along with the related data such as a text and an icon.
sap.ui.commons.RowRepeaterSorter.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new RowRepeaterSorter. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getText text} : string
    • {@link #getIcon icon} : string
    • {@link #getSorter sorter} : object
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Element#constructor sap.ui.core.Element} can be used as well.
sap.ui.commons.RowRepeaterSorter.helpDescription:
Deprecated! Since 1.38 Instead, use the sap.ui.table.Table control.
This element is used by the RowRepeater and allows to define a sorter in this context along with the related data such as a text and an icon.

sap.ui.commons.AccordionSection.description: Represents a panel which is a container for other controls. The container does not have any layout function.
sap.ui.commons.AccordionSection.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new AccordionSection. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getMaxHeight maxHeight} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize
    • {@link #getEnabled enabled} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getCollapsed collapsed} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getTitle title} : string
  • Aggregations
    • {@link #getContent content} : sap.ui.core.Control[] (default)
  • Events
    • {@link #event:scroll scroll} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Element#constructor sap.ui.core.Element} can be used as well.
sap.ui.commons.AccordionSection.helpDescription:
Deprecated! Since 1.38 undefined
Represents a panel which is a container for other controls. The container does not have any layout function.

content.description: Aggregates the controls that are contained in the panel. The control layout is browser-dependent. For a stable content layout, use a layout control as direct single child. When the panel dimensions are set, the child control may have width and height of 100%; when the panel dimensions are not set, the child defines the panel size.

sap.ui.commons.CheckBox.description: Provides a box which can be flagged, the box has a label. A check box can either stand alone, or in a group with other check boxes. As an option, the boxes can initially be set to status 'Not Editable'.
sap.ui.commons.CheckBox.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new CheckBox. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getChecked checked} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getText text} : string
    • {@link #getEnabled enabled} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getEditable editable} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getValueState valueState} : sap.ui.core.ValueState (default: None)
    • {@link #getWidth width} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize
    • {@link #getTextDirection textDirection} : sap.ui.core.TextDirection (default: Inherit)
    • {@link #getName name} : string
  • Associations
    • {@link #getAriaDescribedBy ariaDescribedBy} : (sap.ui.core.ID | sap.ui.core.Control)[]
    • {@link #getAriaLabelledBy ariaLabelledBy} : (sap.ui.core.ID | sap.ui.core.Control)[]
  • Events
    • {@link #event:change change} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Control#constructor sap.ui.core.Control} can be used as well.
sap.ui.commons.CheckBox.helpDescription:
Deprecated! Since 1.38 Instead, use the sap.m.CheckBox control.
Provides a box which can be flagged, the box has a label. A check box can either stand alone, or in a group with other check boxes. As an option, the boxes can initially be set to status 'Not Editable'.

visible.description: Whether the control should be visible on the screen. If set to false, a placeholder will be rendered to mark the location of the invisible control in the DOM of the current page. The placeholder will be hidden and have zero dimensions (display: none). See {@link sap.ui.core.RenderManager#writeInvisiblePlaceholderData RenderManager#writeInvisiblePlaceholderData} for details.

busyIndicatorSize.description: The size of the BusyIndicator. For controls with a width smaller 3rem a sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Small should be used. If the size could vary in width and the width could get smaller than 3rem, the sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Auto option could be used. The default is set to sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Medium For a full screen BusyIndicator use sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Large.
busyIndicatorSize.helpDescription: The size of the BusyIndicator. For controls with a width smaller 3rem a sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Small should be used. The default is set to sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Medium For a full screen BusyIndicator use sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Large.

sap.ui.commons.MessageBar.description: Creates an instance of a MessageBar Control, for displaying messages.
sap.ui.commons.MessageBar.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new MessageBar. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getAnchorID anchorID} : string (default: )
    • {@link #getVisible visible} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getMaxToasted maxToasted} : int (default: 3)
    • {@link #getMaxListed maxListed} : int (default: 7)
    • {@link #getAnchorSnapPoint anchorSnapPoint} : string (default: begin top)
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Control#constructor sap.ui.core.Control} can be used as well.
sap.ui.commons.MessageBar.helpDescription:
Deprecated! Since 1.4.0 Instead, use the sap.m.MessagePopover control.
Creates an instance of a MessageBar Control, for displaying messages.

anchorSnapPoint.description: Type: sap.ui.core.Popup.Dock SnapPoint of MessageBar over anchorId. Note: Use "begin" or "end" for RTL support. Note: "center" is not indicated, as positioning is only set once, either via the css "left" or the "right" attribute. Therefore a MessageBar will only be extended in one direction, as Messages come in.

sap.ui.commons.Panel.description: Represents a container with scroll functionality, that can be used for text and controls. The Panel does not layout the embedded controls.
sap.ui.commons.Panel.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new Panel. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getWidth width} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize (default: 100%)
    • {@link #getHeight height} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize
    • {@link #getEnabled enabled} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getScrollLeft scrollLeft} : int (default: 0)
    • {@link #getScrollTop scrollTop} : int (default: 0)
    • {@link #getApplyContentPadding applyContentPadding} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getCollapsed collapsed} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getAreaDesign areaDesign} : sap.ui.commons.enums.AreaDesign (default: Fill)
    • {@link #getBorderDesign borderDesign} : sap.ui.commons.enums.BorderDesign (default: Box)
    • {@link #getShowCollapseIcon showCollapseIcon} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getText text} : string
  • Aggregations
    • {@link #getContent content} : sap.ui.core.Control[] (default)
    • {@link #getTitle title} : sap.ui.core.Title
    • {@link #getButtons buttons} : sap.ui.commons.Button[]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Control#constructor sap.ui.core.Control} can be used as well.
sap.ui.commons.Panel.helpDescription:
Deprecated! Since 1.38 Instead, use the sap.m.Panel control.
Represents a container with scroll functionality, that can be used for text and controls. The Panel does not layout the embedded controls.

If the size could vary in width and the width could get smaller than 3rem, the sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Auto option could be used. The default is set to sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Medium For a full screen BusyIndicator use sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Large.

sap.ui.commons.Button.description: Enables users to trigger actions such as save or print. For the button UI, you can define some text or an icon, or both.
sap.ui.commons.Button.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new Button. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getText text} : string (default: )
    • {@link #getEnabled enabled} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getWidth width} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize
    • {@link #getHelpId helpId} : string (default: )
    • {@link #getIcon icon} : sap.ui.core.URI (default: )
    • {@link #getIconHovered iconHovered} : sap.ui.core.URI (default: )
    • {@link #getIconSelected iconSelected} : sap.ui.core.URI (default: )
    • {@link #getIconFirst iconFirst} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getHeight height} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize
    • {@link #getStyled styled} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getLite lite} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getStyle style} : sap.ui.commons.ButtonStyle (default: Default)
  • Associations
    • {@link #getAriaDescribedBy ariaDescribedBy} : (sap.ui.core.ID | sap.ui.core.Control)[]
    • {@link #getAriaLabelledBy ariaLabelledBy} : (sap.ui.core.ID | sap.ui.core.Control)[]
  • Events
    • {@link #event:press press} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Control#constructor sap.ui.core.Control} can be used as well.
sap.ui.commons.Button.helpDescription:
Deprecated! Since 1.38 Instead, use the sap.m.Button control.
Enables users to trigger actions such as save or print. For the button UI, you can define some text or an icon, or both.

sap.ui.commons.RowRepeater.description: This control displays items in a stacked list format, allowing the user to page in order to see more items or to use the offered filtering and sorting capabilities in order to manipulate the displayed data.
sap.ui.commons.RowRepeater.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new RowRepeater. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getNumberOfRows numberOfRows} : int (default: 5)
    • {@link #getCurrentPage currentPage} : int (default: 1)
    • {@link #getShowMoreSteps showMoreSteps} : int (default: 0)
    • {@link #getFixedRowHeight fixedRowHeight} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize (default: )
    • {@link #getDesign design} : sap.ui.commons.RowRepeaterDesign (default: Standard)
    • {@link #getThreshold threshold} : int
  • Aggregations
    • {@link #getRows rows} : sap.ui.core.Control[] (default)
    • {@link #getTitle title} : sap.ui.core.Title
    • {@link #getFilters filters} : sap.ui.commons.RowRepeaterFilter[]
    • {@link #getSorters sorters} : sap.ui.commons.RowRepeaterSorter[]
    • {@link #getNoData noData} : sap.ui.core.Control
  • Events
    • {@link #event:filter filter} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:sort sort} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:page page} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:resize resize} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Control#constructor sap.ui.core.Control} can be used as well.
sap.ui.commons.RowRepeater.helpDescription:
Deprecated! Since 1.38 Instead, use the sap.ui.table.Table control.
This control displays items in a stacked list format, allowing the user to page in order to see more items or to use the offered filtering and sorting capabilities in order to manipulate the displayed data.

sap.ui.commons.TextView.description: Is used to display some continous text. The control can inherit the text direction from its parent control.
sap.ui.commons.TextView.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new TextView. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getText text} : string (default: )
    • {@link #getTextDirection textDirection} : sap.ui.core.TextDirection (default: Inherit)
    • {@link #getEnabled enabled} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getHelpId helpId} : string (default: )
    • {@link #getAccessibleRole accessibleRole} : sap.ui.core.AccessibleRole
    • {@link #getDesign design} : sap.ui.commons.TextViewDesign (default: Standard)
    • {@link #getWrapping wrapping} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getSemanticColor semanticColor} : sap.ui.commons.TextViewColor (default: Default)
    • {@link #getTextAlign textAlign} : sap.ui.core.TextAlign (default: Begin)
    • {@link #getWidth width} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize
  • Associations
    • {@link #getAriaDescribedBy ariaDescribedBy} : (sap.ui.core.ID | sap.ui.core.Control)[]
    • {@link #getAriaLabelledBy ariaLabelledBy} : (sap.ui.core.ID | sap.ui.core.Control)[]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Control#constructor sap.ui.core.Control} can be used as well.
sap.ui.commons.TextView.helpDescription:
Deprecated! Since 1.38 undefined
Is used to display some continous text. The control can inherit the text direction from its parent control.

sap.ui.commons.Tree.description: Simple tree to display item in a hierarchical way
sap.ui.commons.Tree.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new Tree. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getTitle title} : string
    • {@link #getWidth width} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize (default: auto)
    • {@link #getHeight height} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize (default: auto)
    • {@link #getShowHeader showHeader} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getShowHeaderIcons showHeaderIcons} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getShowHorizontalScrollbar showHorizontalScrollbar} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getMinWidth minWidth} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize
    • {@link #getSelectionMode selectionMode} : sap.ui.commons.TreeSelectionMode (default: Legacy)
  • Aggregations
    • {@link #getNodes nodes} : sap.ui.commons.TreeNode[] (default)
  • Events
    • {@link #event:select select} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:selectionChange selectionChange} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Control#constructor sap.ui.core.Control} can be used as well.
sap.ui.commons.Tree.helpDescription:
Deprecated! Since 1.38 undefined
Simple tree to display item in a hierarchical way

sap.ui.commons.DatePicker.description: Allows end users to interact with dates. Entries can directly be written in, or selected from a calendar pad. Note: Dates can always be manually entered in the fix YYYYMMDD format, on top of the flexible "locale" format. If the value is provided via data binding, using a Date.type the formatter of the Date.type is used. Since version 1.22 the unified.Calendar is used inside the datePicker. So applications using the DatePicker should load the unified library. Otherwise it will be loaded the first time a DatePicker is opened.
sap.ui.commons.DatePicker.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new DatePicker. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getLocale locale} : string
    • {@link #getYyyymmdd yyyymmdd} : string
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.commons.TextField#constructor sap.ui.commons.TextField} can be used as well.
sap.ui.commons.DatePicker.helpDescription:
Deprecated! Since 1.38 Instead, use the sap.m.DatePicker control.
Allows end users to interact with dates. Entries can directly be written in, or selected from a calendar pad. Note: Dates can always be manually entered in the fix YYYYMMDD format, on top of the flexible "locale" format. If the value is provided via data binding, using a Date.type the formatter of the Date.type is used. Since version 1.22 the unified.Calendar is used inside the datePicker. So applications using the DatePicker should load the unified library. Otherwise it will be loaded the first time a DatePicker is opened.

listBox.description: Using this method, you provide a ListBox control. This allows reuse of item lists in different controls. Either a control id can be used as new target, or a control instance. Note: The ListBox must not be rendered somewhere in the UI. But if you want to bind the ListBox items to a model it must be in the control tree. So we suggest to add it as dependent somewhere (e.g. to the view or the first used ComboBox). If it is not set as child or dependant to an other control it will be automatically set as dependent to the first ComboBox where it is assigned.
listBox.helpDescription: Using this method, you provide a ListBox control. This allows reuse of item lists in different controls. Either a control id can be used as new target, or a control instance. Note: The ListBox must not be rendered somewhere in the UI. But if you want to bind the ListBox items to a model it must be in the control tree. So we suggest to add it as dependent somewhere (e.g. to the view or the first used ComboBox). If it is not set as child or dependant to an other control it will be automatically set as dependent to the first ComboBox where it is assigned.

sap.ui.commons.DropdownBox.description: The control provides a field that allows end users to an entry out of a list of pre-defined items. The choosable items can be provided in the form of a complete ListBox, single ListItems.
sap.ui.commons.DropdownBox.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new DropdownBox. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getSearchHelpEnabled searchHelpEnabled} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getSearchHelpText searchHelpText} : string
    • {@link #getSearchHelpAdditionalText searchHelpAdditionalText} : string
    • {@link #getSearchHelpIcon searchHelpIcon} : sap.ui.core.URI
    • {@link #getMaxHistoryItems maxHistoryItems} : int (default: 0)
  • Events
    • {@link #event:searchHelp searchHelp} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.commons.ComboBox#constructor sap.ui.commons.ComboBox} can be used as well.
sap.ui.commons.DropdownBox.helpDescription:
Deprecated! Since 1.38 Instead, use the sap.m.ComboBox control.
The control provides a field that allows end users to an entry out of a list of pre-defined items. The choosable items can be provided in the form of a complete ListBox, single ListItems.

The default is set to sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Medium For a full screen BusyIndicator use sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Large.

The interactive control is displayed either as a horizontal or a vertical line with two pointers and units of measurement. Users can move the pointers along the line to change a range with graphical support.

sap.ui.commons.MenuBar.description: Represents a user interface area which is the entry point for menus with their menu items. MenuBar is useful for applications which shall offer a set of actions that shall be provided in a structured way. The MenuBar contains the menu titles from where users navigate to the single items. The control supports for example long menu item texts, automated scrolling for menu items when the browser space is not large enough to display all items, defining images for single or all items in a menu, automated layouting of items with or w/o image, and active/non-active items.
sap.ui.commons.MenuBar.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new MenuBar. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getEnabled enabled} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getWidth width} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize (default: 100%)
    • {@link #getDesign design} : sap.ui.commons.MenuBarDesign (default: Standard)
  • Aggregations
    • {@link #getItems items} : sap.ui.unified.MenuItem[] (default)
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Control#constructor sap.ui.core.Control} can be used as well.
sap.ui.commons.MenuBar.helpDescription:
Deprecated! Since 1.38 Instead, use the sap.m.OverflowToolbar control.
Represents a user interface area which is the entry point for menus with their menu items. MenuBar is useful for applications which shall offer a set of actions that shall be provided in a structured way. The MenuBar contains the menu titles from where users navigate to the single items. The control supports for example long menu item texts, automated scrolling for menu items when the browser space is not large enough to display all items, defining images for single or all items in a menu, automated layouting of items with or w/o image, and active/non-active items.

sap.ui.commons.layout.MatrixLayout.description:
A matrix layout arranges controls in a grid structure, using rows which need not have the same number of cells.

It uses predefined cell classes that guarantee appropriate distances between cells in the grid. The cell's vGutter property lets you specify additional horizontal distances easily. You can set these additional distances (known as gutters) with or without separators. The distance for each cell is specified by assigning a specific enumeration value of the class LayoutCellSeparator of the matrix data object.

You should avoid nesting matrix layouts. You should only use a matrix layout if you need to align controls horizontally across rows.
sap.ui.commons.layout.MatrixLayout.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new layout/MatrixLayout. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getWidth width} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize
    • {@link #getHeight height} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize
    • {@link #getLayoutFixed layoutFixed} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getColumns columns} : int
    • {@link #getWidths widths} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize[]
  • Aggregations
    • {@link #getRows rows} : sap.ui.commons.layout.MatrixLayoutRow[] (default)
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Control#constructor sap.ui.core.Control} can be used as well.
sap.ui.commons.layout.MatrixLayout.helpDescription:
Deprecated! Since 1.38 Instead, use the sap.ui.layout.Grid control.

A matrix layout arranges controls in a grid structure, using rows which need not have the same number of cells.

It uses predefined cell classes that guarantee appropriate distances between cells in the grid. The cell's vGutter property lets you specify additional horizontal distances easily. You can set these additional distances (known as gutters) with or without separators. The distance for each cell is specified by assigning a specific enumeration value of the class LayoutCellSeparator of the matrix data object.

You should avoid nesting matrix layouts. You should only use a matrix layout if you need to align controls horizontally across rows.
